unnormalised: The year was 2008. I remember clearly the day my father, Rakesh Kumar, brought home our first computer. It was a bulky desktop with a CRT monitor, running Windows XP. He’d saved up for months, splurging ₹25,000 from his salary as a government clerk. For him, and for me, it wasn’t just a machine; it was a portal to a new world of information technology.
normalised: The year was two thousand and eight. I remember clearly the day my father, Rakesh Kumar, brought home our first computer. It was a bulky desktop with a C-R-T monitor, running Windows X-P. He’d saved up for months, splurging rupee twenty five thousand from his salary as a government clerk. For him, and for me, it wasn’t just a machine; it was a portal to a new world of information technology.

unnormalised: Initially, the dial-up connection was frustratingly slow. Downloading a 5MB song could take ages. Still, the possibilities were intoxicating. I spent hours exploring websites, learning basic HTML from online tutorials (the infamous geocities!), and chatting with friends on Yahoo Messenger. My younger sister, Priya, mostly used it to play flash games on Miniclip. com. My father learned excel basics, a big leap from maintaining ledgers by hand.
normalised: Initially, the dial-up connection was frustratingly slow. Downloading a five megabyte song could take ages. Still, the possibilities were intoxicating. I spent hours exploring websites, learning basic H-T-M-L from online tutorials (the infamous geocities!), and chatting with friends on Yahoo Messenger. My younger sister, Priya, mostly used it to play flash games on Miniclip dot com. My father learned excel basics, a big leap from maintaining ledgers by hand.

unnormalised: My interest grew, and I started devouring articles about processors, RAM, and graphics cards. I learned the difference between a Pentium 4 and an Athlon 64. I even attempted to build my own PC, sourcing parts from Nehru Place in Delhi. The first configuration I tried? An Intel Celeron with 128 MB of RAM. Let's just say it wasn't pretty.
normalised: My interest grew, and I started devouring articles about processors, R-A-M, and graphics cards. I learned the difference between a Pentium four and an Athlon sixty four. I even attempted to build my own P-C, sourcing parts from Nehru Place in Delhi. The first configuration I tried? An Intel Celeron with one hundred and twenty eight megabyte of R-A-M. Let's just say it wasn't pretty.

unnormalised: Then came the era of broadband and Wi-Fi. Reliance launched their broadband service and the connection speeds increased exponentially. Suddenly, downloading a 1GB movie was a matter of hours, not days. I started exploring programming, learning C++ and later Python. I found myself drawn to the elegance and power of coding. My father marvelled at how quickly I could troubleshoot problems, often saying, "Beta, you know more about this than the engineer himself!"

unnormalised: Fast forward to today, and I'm working as a software engineer at Infosys in Bangalore. I specialize in AI and machine learning. Priya is now in her final year of B.Tech at IIT Madras. The CRT monitor has been replaced by sleek, high-resolution screens. Windows XP is a distant memory. Yet, I still remember the thrill of that first connection, the spark that ignited my passion for Information Technology.

unnormalised: Looking back, that ₹25,000 investment was the best decision my father ever made. It opened doors not just for me, but for our entire family. It underscores the transformative power of IT, and how access to it, even in its most basic form, can change lives, one dial-up connection at a time.
